Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effects of Neuromuscular Blocking Agents in Neurosurgical Procedures

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary care hospital.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adult patients aged 18-65 undergoing neurosurgery, with no history of neuromuscular disorders.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either succinylcholine or atracurium.

Objective.evidence: To compare the effects of succinylcholine and atracurium on intracranial pressure.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in intracranial pressure measured intraoperatively over a 2-hour period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors and patients.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the succinylcholine group and 97 in the atracurium group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean difference in intracranial pressure was 2.5 mm Hg (95% CI 1.0 to 4.0; p = 0.03) favoring atracurium.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 5% of the succinylcholine group and 3% of the atracurium group, with no severe events.

Funding.evidence: This study was funded by the National Institute of Health.
